comments.commentBody: China will be pacified by a Western woman and she is Hilary Clinton...
Do you think that the Chinese believe that there are risks in that plan? Militarily they would never know what hit them. Yes.

The US Military knows China is the biggest threat.

When China makes its move, the US will be able and willing to defend all of China's neighbors from their Communist aggressors.

China has now reached a point where almost all of its next door neighbors -- except North Korea -- has beef with it. It is not Nazi Germany. That title belongs to Imperial Japan, which slaughtered and enslaved millions of non-Japanese men and women in Asia before most Americans had even heard of Pearl Harbor. Rather, modern China is like The Teenager -- that power that is only now starting to feel its true potential and has not yet made any major geopolitical mistakes. Developed counties, on the other hand, can be seen as the "Thirty or Forty-Somethings"; they have already "gone through" their belligerent phases (whether it's colonialism or proxy wars) and presumably have learned from them.

China has never been in a conflict in which it finds itself in the position it is in today: economically dominant, with an increasingly affluent citizenry that cannot distinguish between a nationalism based on love of country versus nationalism that equates "nation" with "the government".

It will go to war with its neighbors. But perhaps not under Obama's watch. But whoever takes charge in 2016 needs to be prepared to see a major rumble in Asia.

Naturally, our foreign policy "experts" -- who insist that anything worth understanding in the world has something to do with the Middle East -- will miss out on anticipating this Next Major War with its main theater in Asia. But as 2Pac sings: "That's just the way it is."

Don't worry...all nations will ban against China. Chinese behavior is taking care of that.

As for all the other rude things you've said about the US Marines Corps...the dishonorable act of a few bad actors should not be used to besmirch the entire organization. You're being more than a little unfair.

How dare China display such shameless hubris as to create a warring imperialist posture! Who do they think they are...the Imperial Cheney/bush Presidency!?!
'Member...lil GW sat on Cheney's lap and said..."You're right, Fascist-blossom, we need to pick an unfunded fight with a country, or two that is unfunded...coz we can always fund it with debt sold to the Chinese! Brilliant!" And so it was, and so it is. How dare they steal our hubris! Of course, the international community should respond strongly with the real threat of sanctions and military support for the PI, even if that means sending our adulterous, whoring Marines back to Subic for another round of drinking, whoring, and warring...a war that won't end well unless the major nations ban together against China. Think I just got thunderous applause from the Marine Corps.

And I'm pretty dang sure my 100% ancestor Vikings gave me title to the whole world.  Now if I could just buy enough politicians or somehow take over a country I might be able to enforce some of that title.

Americans and Europeans who think this isn't our problem need to think again.  One of the reasons Russia wants to resume missile testing, an apparent threat to Europe, is the Chinese threat, exemplified so well by this issue in Southeast Asia.   One day the owners of Siberia may very well find themselves confronted by a powerful China accusing them of resource inequality, and demanding Siberia be turned over to China, which has an alleged prior claim and more people who "deserve" free access to Russia's resources.

Just who Oort Cloud would you consider a "normal" president?  What policies would that "normal" president have?

Many people here analyze this based on an emotional reaction to the Philippines closing the US bases there.  It would be foolish to make a decision based on such decisions, and not simply on what is best for the US.  China's expansion by overrunning their neighbors.  That's not good for us, and we should resist it.  If we had a normal president, there's no chance China would face off with the US, but in the present circumstances they have no worry.

Everyone should be wary of China's expansionist policies.  They are on a quest for absolute power and Japan, South Korea and the Philippines would do well to coordinate an effective response.

At present, Philippine culture is avidly disposed toward the US in comparison to its well-founded trepidation about China.

Why didn't he compare it to the occupation of the Philippines by the US?

China should receive deference in its claims against the Philippines, who would only demand US military assistance and money to rattle sabors in the region.

The majority of the world has moved on from the ravages of World War II. Why don't you and spare us this ancient sabre rattling.

As far as our infrastructure is concerned, it should never be a question of either/or. Infrastructural fitness is a direct result of tax-funded government planning at all levels. America's current strategy---even a relatively aggressive one---for confronting China is primarily diplomatic. At this point, and for the foreseeable future,,domestic roads and power grids are not in competition with our diplomatic agenda toward China.
America's isolationism exacerbated the start of WWII for about exactly the the same reason: a clear stand on Chinese expansion would lend substantial diplomatic power where China's neighbors clearly have difficult with a viable defense of their own.

No. The article says $200 million over the past decade, not $200 million per year.

Miss Hunter-Gault
This is an important analysis and explanation of the events transpiring at Howard University. Many of us believe it belongs to all of us. Its so difficult to find news stories about many of our institution. I appreciate the manner in which you wove in your personal history to provide context and perspective. I am honored to have interviewed you when you visited Santa Barbara with your first book "In My Place". Yours is also an important story in our history. You can view that interview on-line at the UCSB Library Internet Archive. https://archive.org/details/cusb_000103

Or, maybe Howard should adjust its business model to attract higher income students from any race with a desire to learn about black Americas history, struggle, and rise at one of our premier historically black colleges. Partner with the prestigious historically white liberal arts and social justice universities (who, as the article states are more color blind) and develop programs together. Use the revenue to develop an aggressive admissions outreach program to more states with black students lacking access. Go early, and often to plant the seed and enroll the best of these students. Engage the alumni in this outreach.  Also use program revenue to cross subsidize the best prospects with the least income. As the other historically black campuses decline, Howard has. A chance to leverage its location and strengths to thrive.
Or maybe Howard is struggling because people who do not view the world through the racial lens you do realize an all black college is just as racist as having an all white college.

What's disheartening here is the substantial number of apparently white respondents who are interested enough to read the article but remain profoundly unwilling to acknowledge the racism, institutional and otherwise, that continues to plague American society.  Is it not clear that the difficulties Howard has in recruiting students exist, in part, because there are may qualified Black high school graduates who simply cannot afford to attend it or are unwilling in incur massive debt in order to do so?  Do people not realize that the public schools which most Black kids attend remain largely segregated in fact, if not by law?  Do they not understand what students who emerge from separate and unequal schools gain and lose when they arrive at predominantly white colleges?  Do they not see that the same free market which allegedly rewards say, the Ivy League, with high achieving students continues to discriminate against whole communities based on the race, ethnicity and/or social class of the people who live in them?  If we were truly the increasingly "post-racial," colorblind nation that some imagine us to be, there might not be as strong a need for historically black colleges.  But we're not, so there is.
Thank you, Timm! This is a friendly talk. I hope that once Russia and USA can do something great together instead of looking for "dead bodies" in each other's home. Like we did during WW2! Best

I was chuckling about the crazy stuff described in his article and feeling like a superior American - then I started reading what some of the Russian commentators had to say here and it made me realize how horrible it is for any of us to be rooting for their failure or mocking their shortcomings. We should all be cheering for the Russian's to pull this event off and show the world what they can do. Russia is a great country filled with passionate and wonderful people. I wish you all the very best for a successful Olympics. I'll be watching every minute of coverage and I'm looking forward to learning more about your great country.
Who would hire them?

Historically, between 40 and 50% of new NYC public school teachers quit within 5 years; granted, it has more to do with the insane working conditions of the public school teacher than salary (honestly, do you think we get into this profession for the money?), so I would be more inclined to call the teachers who stay (despite the lack of pay increases, respect from their fellow citizens such as yourself, and adequate classroom resources) brave.

The fact is that 50% of teachers DO QUIT in their first five years. Because while you may think they have a sweet deal, in fact they are underpaid compared to their private sector counterparts and the work is hard. The school day may end at 3 o'clock, but most teachers take piles of grading and paperwork home with them. I know because I live with one. Combined with the vitriolic lack of respect directed at them by the corporate-owned media and usually quite comfortable "indignant taxpayers" most decide that its just not worth it and in fact go find higher-paying work in the private sector. And of course the teacher turnover rate is even higher in schools where students struggle against the effects of poverty.

There are some crummy teachers that cling to their jobs, but most who are not truly dedicated wash out in the first few years. Some good ones burn out too after putting up with too many years of disrespect. If the schools are failing to educate students you should look at the overcrowding of classrooms and the inability of the system to retain experienced teachers before you attack the unions that are the only organized force working against those problems.

Not happy with your pay/lack of raises? Hint: You are more than welcome to quit/resign move on to another job with higher pay if you feel you are not compensated for you skills/value that you add to your union job. Huh? Wow it sure got quiet all of a sudden as any NYC public employee would dare not do such a brave thing as that.

Wasn't there an article just yesterday in the NYT that NYS had a surplus of $200M that Cuomo wanted to apply to tax cuts after he squeezed state workers to the bone last year? If the twice cited Citizens Budget Commission also  issued reports on the cost of the city's corporate welfare policies over the last twenty years, I might find this article slightly credible.
The tunnel Christie cancelled was for freight, not passengers.  But we do need a much better mass transit system in the NYC metro area.

Not really. While the Mediterranean and the Caribbean are full of inhabited islands, the islands claimed by China are uninhabited and have no clear ownership. China's claims are no doubt aggressive, but so are the claims of Taiwan and Vietnam, which are nearly identical to China's. We single out China for criticism not because its claims are more ludicrous than its neighbors', but because it is perceived as a rival of the Western world.
